entry.title: Germanwings crash families could seek damages in the U.S.: lawyer

entry.summary: People lay flowers outside Cologne Cathedral during a memorial service for the 150 victims of Germanwings flight 4U 9525 in Cologne, April 17, 2015.

entry.title: Germanwings crash victims remembered with candles and angels
entry.summary: Lufthansa, the parent company of Germanwings, cancelled its 60th anniversary celebrations set for April following the disaster and set up screens showing live coverage of the memorial service at its main bases.

entry.title: Relatives, Leaders Mourn Germanwings Crash Victims At Memorial Service
entry.summary: Lufthansa, Germanwings' parent airline, took out full-page advertisements in many of the country's leading newspapers expressing sympathy and carried a livestream of the service on its website.

entry.title: Relatives, dignitaries remember Germanwings crash victims
entry.summary: A mourning ceremony is held in the Cathedral in memory of the 150 victims of the Germanwings plane crash last month in the French Alps.

entry.title: Cathedral service mourns victims from Germanwings crash
entry.summary:
Lufthansa chief Carsten Spohr was also to attend, along with three executives of its low-cost subsidiary Germanwings, Thomas Winkelmann, Axel Schmidt and Oliver Wagner, the company said.

The Germanwings Airbus 320 was en route from Barcelona to Duesseldorf when it crashed in the French Alps on March 24, killing everyone aboard, including 72 Germans and 50 Spaniards.

entry.title: Relatives, dignitaries pay tribute to Germanwings crash victims
entry.summary: "We really don't know what was going through his head during those deciding seconds, in the deciding minutes," Gauck told the congregation that also included Chancellor Angela Merkel, ministers from Spain and France, and the heads of Germanwings and its parent airline, Lufthansa.

entry.title: Following Germanwings crash, aviation safety experts weigh ground functions to override pilots
entry.summary: But following the intentional crashing of Germanwings Flight 9525 by the co-pilot, a long-running debate over autonomous jets is resurfacing.

entry.title: Workers clear 80 percent of debris from Germanwings crash
Germanwings plane evacuated after bomb scare
entry.summary: Lufthansa has faced questions about its pilot screening process since the March 24 Germanwings crash which appears to have been caused by a co-pilot who suffered from depression and deliberately steered the plane into a mountain.

entry.title: Germanwings plane evacuated after bomb scare
entry.summary: Germanwings said the pilot of Flight 4U 826 to Milan was taxiing to the runway when he received a call from the air traffic tower at Cologne/Bonn airport to abort the flight.

entry.title: Germanwings plane evacuated after bomb threat received
entry.summary: The tower in Cologne alerted the pilot of the Airbus A320, which was taxiing toward the runway at the time, Germanwings said.

entry.title: Germanwings says plane evacuated at Cologne-Bonn airport after bomb threat received
Germanwings plane crash: 'Fake relative' claims free flights to French Alps
entry.summary: Berlin: German police are looking into an allegation that a woman obtained free flights to the south of France by pretending to be a relative of one of 150 people killed in the Germanwings plane crash last month.

entry.title: Germanwings co-pilot may have spiked pilot's drink with diuretic, report says
German police probe whether woman faked link to crash victim
entry.summary: At the crash site itself, Germanwings and Lufthansa now have responsibility for organizing the removal of the wreckage and clearing up any environmental damage, Lufthansa spokesman Boris Ogursky said.

entry.title: Airline official: Germanwings probe shouldn't set precedent
Airline official: Germanwings probe shouldn't set precedent
entry.summary: "The circumstances of the investigation of the Germanwings accident have been highly unusual, and something that began as an accident investigation morphed into a highly public criminal investigation in which it seemed that every day new revelations were coming out," Tyler said.

entry.title: Airline official: Germanwings probe shouldn't set precedent
entry.summary: The subsequent investigation has focused in large part on the pilot's history of depression and procedures at Germanwings and its parent company, Lufthansa, for screening pilots for mental health issues.

entry.title: Airline industry official expresses concern about the handling of Germanwings investigation
Germanwings crash: Aviation watchdog unaware of co-pilot Andreas Lubitz's medical history
entry.summary: But the Wall Street Journal said the Commission told Berlin in November "to remedy the long-standing problems" - months before the Germanwings crash on March 24.

entry.title: EU agency noted 'non-conformity? with Germany's air safety rules before Germanwings crash
Germanwings plane crash: EU found 'issues' with German aviation regulator
entry.summary: French air accident authority BEA has said its investigation into the Germanwings crash would study "systemic weaknesses" that might have led to the disaster, including psychological profiling.

entry.title: Lufthansa CEO Spohr treading cautiously after Germanwings crash
entry.summary:
Still ahead is the April 17 memorial service in the massive cathedral in Cologne, near where Germanwings is headquartered.

The disaster during the flight from Barcelona to Duesseldorf has subjected the airline to scrutiny over whether Lubitz should have been allowed to join its budget subsidiary Germanwings in 2013.

entry.title: France halts search for bodies at Germanwings crash site
entry.summary: Lufthansa is the parent company of the lowcost Germanwings carrier.

entry.summary: Germanwings flight 4U814, with 123 passengers and five crew members on board, took off from Cologne at 9.55 a.m. local time (0355 EDT).

entry.title: Michele Bachmann compares Obama to Germanwings co-pilot
Germanwings co-pilot increased speed as jet went down
Germanwings co-pilot repeatedly accelerated plane, investigators say
entry.summary: The co-pilot of the doomed Germanwings flight repeatedly sped up the plane as he used the automatic pilot to descend the A320 into the Alps, the French air accident investigation agency said Friday.

entry.title: Investigators Find Body Parts From All 150 Germanwings Victims

Germanwings co-pilot lied to doctors about sick leave -Bild
entry.summary:
Although Lubitz gave doctors information about his job as a pilot, and in some cases about his employer Germanwings, he deliberately concealed the fact that he was still working, the paper said.

Germanwings parent Lufthansa said on Tuesday that when Lubitz resumed pilot training in 2009 he provided the flight school with medical documents showing he had gone through a "previous episode of severe depression".

entry.title: LUFTHANSA KNEW: Airline admits co-pilot reported depression in 2009 - VIDEO: Lufthansa admits it knew of co-pilot's 'depressive episode' - French Alps crash shows psychiatrists cannot be last line of defense
entry.summary: The Germanwings crash has already produced some changes in aviation procedures.

entry.title: Germanwings plane crash: passenger video 'found'
entry.summary: London: A video of the last moments on the doomed Germanwings plane has been found on a mobile phone memory card at the crash site in the French Alps, according to reports.

entry.title: Germanwings co-pilot Andreas Lubitz admitted depression
entry.summary:
Berlin: The co-pilot suspected of deliberately crashing a Germanwings plane in the French Alps had informed his employer that he had undergone a "previous episode of severe depression".

Lufthansa which owns Germanwings, said 27-year-old Andreas Lubitz had told the company in 2009 about his illness after interrupting his flight training.

entry.title: Germanwings crash: Lubitz told Lufthansa of depression
entry.summary: Lawyers representing some of the families of victims of the Germanwings crash called on Tuesday for more psychiatric testing of pilots.

entry.title: Lufthansa: Co-pilot told flight school of depressive episode
entry.summary: The revelation that officials Lufthansa had been informed of Lubitz's psychological problems raises further questions about why he was allowed to become a pilot for its subsidiary, Germanwings, in September 2013.

entry.title: Psychological profiling, doors focus of French Germanwings probe
entry.summary: Lufthansa, parent company of Germanwings, has said Lubitz had passed suitability tests and the annual medical check.

entry.title: France eyes cockpit entry, psychological screening rules after Germanwings crash
entry.summary:
BEA said it aims to provide a "detailed analysis" of the Germanwings cockpit voice recorder and any other flight data - but it also plans to widen its search to examine issues that could be problematic for all airlines.

Several airlines and the European aviation regulator have already changed procedures after the Germanwings crash, announcing last week that they now recommend having two people in the cockpit at all times.

entry.title: Lufthansa insurers to set aside $300 million for Germanwings crash
entry.summary: Lufthansa -- Germanwings' parent company -- offered immediate aid last week of up to 50,000 euros ($54,250) per passenger to relatives of the victims.

entry.title: Families of victims of Germanwings plane crash could face up to four months waiting for loved ones remains to be identifiedÂ
entry.summary: The families of victims of the Germanwings plane crash face a wait of up to four months for the remains of their loved ones to be identified.

entry.title: Crash pilot had been treated for suicidal tendencies

entry.title: Lufthansa CEO faces tough test after Germanwings crash
entry.summary: "It was a big step to use Germanwings for European short-haul flights outside of Frankfurt and Munich and that commercial side of the business has to continue," he said.

entry.title: Prosecutors: Germanwings co-pilot was treated years ago for suicidal tendencies

Horrifying transcript gives timeline of Germanwings plane crash in Alps
entry.summary:
Germanwings Flight 9525 was just under halfway along its route when Lubitz appeared to have deliberately set the autopilot to automatic descent, causing it to crash into the mountain Tuesday.

Germanwings and its parent company, Lufthansa, say they never received a sick note from Lubitz, suggesting he hid his illness from the airline.

entry.summary: Berlin: Lufthansa said it will introduce new rules requiring two crew members to be in the cockpit at all times after one of the pilots at its Germanwings unit crashed a plane in the French Alps.

entry.title: Germanwings flight 4U9525 crash: Investigators find torn up sick notes in Andreas Lubitz's home

Police carry computer, a box and bags out of the residence of the parents of Andreas Lubitz, co-pilot on Germanwings flight 4U9525 in Montabaur, Germany.

entry.title: Prosecutors: Evidence Germanwings co-pilot hid illness, but no suicide note found
entry.summary: People in Montabaur who knew Lubitz told AP they were shocked at the allegations that he could have intentionally crashed the plane, saying he had been thrilled with his job at Germanwings and seemed to be "very happy."

entry.title: Germanwings co-pilot battled depression: Media
entry.summary: French investigators, who are in charge of the probe into the plane crash, believe the 27-year-old locked himself inside the cockpit and then intentionally smashed the Germanwings plane into a mountainside on Tuesday during a flight from Barcelona to Duesseldorf.

entry.title: The Latest: Co-pilot may have hid illness from employers
entry.summary: After the media reports, a prosecutor announced that cockpit recordings indicate the co-pilot of the Germanwings A320 jet intentionally flew the plane into a mountain on Tuesday.

entry.title: German prosecutors: Germanwings co-pilot hid illness from employers
entry.summary: "In these dark hours our full attention belongs to the emotional support of the relatives and friends of the victims of Flight 9525," Germanwings CEO Thomas Winkelmann said in a statement.

entry.title: Germanwings flight 4U9525 crash: captain reportedly tried to force way through cockpit door with axe
entry.summary: Berlin: The captain locked out of the cockpit of the Germanwings plane that crashed in the French Alps reportedly used an axe to try to force his way back in.

entry.title: Airlines introduce two-person cockpit rule after Germanwings crash
entry.summary: That is precisely what French prosecutors suspect happened on the Germanwings flight on Tuesday.

entry.title: Germanwings flight 4U9525 crash: captain reportedly tried to force way through cockpit door with axe
entry.summary:
Germanwings has confirmed an axe was on board the aircraft.

Germanwings planes require an access code to open the door but the airline, which is owned by Lufthansa, did not wish on Thursday to give details "for security reasons".

entry.title: Germanwings co-pilot had serious depressive episode: Bild newspaper
Airlines introduce two-person cockpit rule after Germanwings crash
entry.summary: Among the companies that did not announce such a policy change was Germanwings parent Lufthansa, whose CEO Carsten Spohr said he believed it was unnecessary.

entry.title: Few precedents seen as Germanwings investigation points to deliberate crash
entry.summary: If Andreas Lubitz, Germanwings flight 9525's 27-year-old co-pilot, was determined to kill himself, he would not be the first to use an aeroplane as a tool for self-destruction or to kill others in the process.

entry.title: Germanwings plane crash: co-pilot Andreas Lubitz was 'happy he had the job' with airline
entry.summary:
A sign reading'Crash landing path' stands next to field at the LSC Westerwald flight club in Montabaur where the Germanwings co-pilot Andreas Lubitz had been a member.

Andreas Lubitz first took to the skies as a teenage glider pilot flying from a grass runway in western Germany and never showed any sign he was anything but thrilled to have landed a job with Germanwings, those who taught him the trade say.

entry.title: German co-pilot 'appears to have crashed plane deliberately'
entry.summary: This is an undated image taken from Facebook of Germanwings co-pilot Andreas Lubitz in San Francisco California.

entry.title: Pilot locked out of cockpit before Germanwings crash: report
entry.summary: A young German co-pilot locked himself alone in the cockpit of Germanwings flight 9525 and set it on course to crash into an Alpine mountain, killing all 150 people on board including himself, prosecutors said on Thursday.

entry.title: Germanwings: Andreas Lubitz breakdown six years ago offers clue
entry.summary:
Yet, in what Chancellor Angela Merkel described as a "new, simply incomprehensible" dimension to the Germanwings air disaster, it appeared that Lubitz was responsible for the deaths of 149 people.

Mr Radker last saw Lubitz last autumn, when the Germanwings pilot returned to the club to renew his light aircraft flying licence and take part in the club's barbecue, which he attended with a girlfriend.

Carsten Spohr, the chief executive of Lufthansa, Germanwings' parent company, said that Lubitz "took a break in his training six years ago. Then he did the tests [technical and psychological] again. And he was deemed 100 per cent fit to fly".

entry.title: Co-pilot who crashed jet was 'very happy' with Germanwings job
entry.summary: MONTABAUR (Germany): Andreas Lubitz never appeared anything but thrilled to have landed a pilot's job with Germanwings, according to those who helped him learn to fly as a teenager in this town in the forested hills of western Germany.

entry.title: Co-pilot was 'very happy' with Germanwings job
entry.summary: Investigators enter the house where the co-pilot of the crashed Germanwings airliner jet is supposed to have lived in an apartment, in Duesseldorf, Germany, Thursday March 26, 2015.

entry.title: Germanwings plane crash: co-pilot Andreas Lubitz was 'happy he had the job' with airline
entry.summary: Montabaur, Germany: Co-pilot Andreas Lubitz was silent as Germanwings Flight 9525 from Barcelona to Dusseldorf descended for eight minutes before crashing in the French Alps on Tuesday, authorities said.

entry.title: Co-pilot appears to have crashed Germanwings plane deliberately: Prosecutor [Photos] [Video]
entry.summary:
The CEO of Lufthansa, parent company of Germanwings, said its air crew were picked carefully and subjected to psychological vetting.

The co-pilot suspected of deliberately crashing a Germanwings jet into the French Alps on Tuesday has been identified as 28-year-old Andreas Lubitz.

entry.title: Germanwings co-pilot Andreas Lubitz was thrilled to have landed the job
entry.summary: After completing his training, he spent an 11-month waiting period working as a flight attendant before becoming a co-pilot on the Germanwings A320 fleet.

entry.title: Germanwings co-pilot Andreas Lubitz was '100% fit to fly'
Germanwings Co-Pilot Was 'Very Happy' With Germanwings Job
entry.summary:
On Thursday, French prosecutors said Lubitz, the co-pilot of Germanwings Flight 9525, "intentionally" crashed the jet into the side of a mountain.

After starting his job with Germanwings in September 2013, Lubitz was upbeat when he returned to the LSC Westerwald e.V glider club in the fall to renew his glider pilots' license with 20 or so takeoffs.

Club chairman Klaus Radke said he rejected Marseille prosecutors' conclusion that Lubitz put the Germanwings flight intentionally into a descent and dove it into the French Alps when the pilot had left the cockpit.

entry.title: Co-pilot was ?very happy' with Germanwings job
entry.summary: "He was happy he had the job with Germanwings and he was doing well," said longtime club member Peter Ruecker, who watched him learn to fly.

entry.title: Germanwings co-pilot likely crashed jet deliberately: prosecutor
Official: 1 pilot locked out of crash plane cockpit
entry.summary:
Lufthansa has refused to identify the pilots, or give details of ages and nationality, but it said the co-pilot joined Germanwings in September 2013, directly after training, and had flown 630 hours.

The captain had more than 6,000 hours of flying time and been Germanwings pilot since May 2014, having previously flown for Lufthansa and Condor, Lufthansa said.

entry.title: Germanwings plane crash: A320 pilot says co-pilot can be locked out of cockpit
entry.summary: 26 Mar An investigator says evidence indicates a pilot was unable to get back into the cockpit before the Germanwings plane crashed in France on Tuesday.

entry.title: Germanwings plane crash: A320 pilot says co-pilot can be locked out of cockpit
entry.summary: 26 Mar Voice recordings recovered from one of the black boxes from the downed Germanwings flight 4U9525 reportedly reveal fresh clues to the plane's demise.

entry.title: Germanwings plane crash: A320 pilot says co-pilot can be locked out of cockpit
entry.summary: The New York Times has reported, citing an official involved in the Germanwings crash investigation, that the cockpit voice recorder shows one of the pilots had left the flight deck and could not regain entry.

entry.title: The Latest: Germanwings investigation could take months
entry.summary: The director of France's aviation investigative agency says there currently is not the "slightest explanation" for what caused the Germanwings plane to lose altitude and crash in the Alps.

entry.title: The Latest: Germanwings crash victims from Spain up to 51
entry.summary:
This is an undated image of Paul Andrew Bramley who died in the Germanwings plane crash provided by his family Wednesday March 25, 2015.

Sixteen 10th-grade students from a town in western Germany and two of their teachers had just spent a week on an exchange near Barcelona and were less than an hour from landing when their Germanwings flight crashed in southern France.

Germanwings aircrafts are parked at the airport in Cologne, Wednesday March 25, 2015, a day after a Germanwings aircraft crashed in France on the way from Barcelona, Spain, to Duesseldorf, Germany, killing 150 people.

U.S. President Barack Obama has called Spanish Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy to express his condolences following the crash of the Germanwings plane in which at least 35 Spaniards died.

entry.title: Cockpit voice recorder hoped to unravel 'inexplicable' Germanwings crash
entry.summary: Germanwings said it cancelled one flight on Wednesday and was using 11 planes from other carriers for about 40 flights after some of its crew members had refused to fly.

entry.title: How investigators will determine why Germanwings jet crashed
entry.summary: NEW YORK (AP) - Cockpit voice recordings and, hopefully, flight data will provide the main clues to investigators trying to understand what caused Germanwings Flight 9525 to crash.

entry.title: The Latest: Germanwings crash victims from Spain up to 51
entry.summary:
Executives, pilots and employees of German airline Lufthansa have held a minute of silence at company headquarters for the 150 people who died in the Germanwings crash.

He says that authorities are nevertheless investigating all possible causes for the crash of a Germanwings flight from Barcelona to Spain on Tuesday in which 144 passengers and six crew members died.

entry.title: Germanwings crash: Just how safe is the Airbus A320?
entry.summary:
The passenger flight run by German airline Germanwings from Barcelona to Dusseldorf, Flight 9525, was carrying six crew members and 144 passengers, including a group of 16 schoolchildren, all of whom are now presumed dead.

entry.title: Germanwings plane crash: victims' remains airlifted from remote Alps site
entry.summary:
Seyne-les-Alpes: Helicopters have begun airlifting the remains of the victims of the Germanwings plane crash from the disaster site in the French Alps.

Lufthansa, the parent company of Germanwings, is arranging two flights from Spain and Germany to take family members of the victims to visit the accident site.

entry.title: Germanwings flight 4U9525 disaster: Laborious 'black box' inquiry aims to unlock crash cause
entry.summary:
One of the Germanwings Airbus A320's two 'black boxes' was found hours after Tuesday's crash and will come under scrutiny at the spartan offices of France's Bureau d'Enquete d'Accidents (BEA, or office of accident investigations.)

entry.title: Germanwings flight 4U9525 disaster: Laborious 'black box' inquiry aims to unlock crash cause

entry.title: Germanwings flight 4U9525 disaster: Laborious 'black box' inquiry aims to unlock crash cause
entry.summary: Germanwings said 72 Germans were killed in Tuesday's crash, the first major air passenger disaster on French soil since the 2000 Concorde accident just outside Paris.

entry.title: Details of victims in the crash of Germanwings Flight 9525
entry.summary: A Spanish opera house said Tuesday, March 24, 2015 German contralto Maria Radner along with her husband and baby, were among the 150 victims of the Germanwings plane crash in the French Alps.

entry.title: Small town mourns 18 young lives lost in Germanwings crash
entry.summary: Ulrich Wessel, principal of the Joseph-Koenig-Gymnasium high school, the day after 16 students and two teachers from the school were among passengers who were killed on Germanwings flight 4U9525.

entry.title: The Latest: Crashed jet's late takeoff was due to congestion
entry.summary:
The director of France's aviation investigative agency says audio has been recovered from the cockpit recorder salvaged from the crash of the Germanwings plane in the Alps.

France's aviation investigation bureau has released photos of the badly mangled voice data recorder from the Germanwings flight that crashed into an Alpine mountainside.

entry.title: How investigators will determine why Germanwings jet crashed
Team narrowly escaped doomed Germanwings flight
entry.summary:
The team had considered four possible routes, one of which was on Germanwings flight 4U 9525, to take their players and staff home to Stockholm from a training camp in Barcelona.

The team ended up flying groups home on three separate flights, rejecting the Germanwings option because of the long wait for a connection in Duesseldorf.

entry.title: Germanwings crash: Air traffic controllers 'tried three times to radio pilots with no response'
entry.summary: Lufthansa, the parent company of Germanwings, said it was working on the assumption the crash was an "accident".

entry.title: Germanwings crash: Terrorism unlikely as cause of plane crash, says interior minister Bernard Cazeneuve
entry.summary: Asked whether something similar could have occurred on Tuesday, Germanwings managing director Thomas Winkelmann said, "At this time this evening, we are ruling out a possible cause in this area."

entry.title: Search resumes at Germanwings Flight 9525 crash site
Germanwings plane crash: Melbourne family of Carol and Greig Friday 'crippled with sadness'
entry.summary: A Melbourne family is "crippled with sadness" after mother and son Carol Friday and Greig Friday were among the 150 killed when Germanwings flight 4U9525 came down in southern France.

entry.title: Rescuers struggle to recover bodies in Germanwings French Alps crash
entry.summary: Germanwings executive Thomas Winkelmann said the pilot had "more than 10 years of experience" and some 6,000 flying hours on an Airbus jet under his belt.

entry.title: Germanwings forced to cancel 7 flights

entry.summary: A Germanwings passenger jet carrying at least 150 people crashed Tuesday in a snowy, remote section of the French Alps, sounding like an avalanche as it scattered pulverized debris across the mountain.

entry.title: The Latest: Germanwings forced to cancel 7 flights
entry.summary: Spohr expressed satisfaction that authorities had found the first black box from the Germanwings plane that crashed on its way from Barcelona to Duesseldorf and said he would not speculate on the cause of the crash until its data had been analyzed.

entry.title: Germanwings cancels seven flights as crews too upset to fly after tragic crash
entry.summary: "One must not forget: many of our Germanwings crews have known crew members who were onboard the crashed plane," Carsten Spohr said.

entry.title: 16 German high school students among plane crash victims
entry.summary: A Germanwings plane from Barcelona crashed on its way to Duesseldorf over the French alps, 16 school children and 2 teachers from Haltern were among the 150 people on board.

entry.title: Germanwings Flight 9525: "Everything is pulverized"
entry.summary: "We cannot say at the moment why our colleague went into the descent, and so quickly and without previously consulting air traffic control," said Germanwings' director of flight operations, Stefan-Kenan Scheib.

entry.title: Germanwings Flight 4U9525: Airbus A320 plane crashes in French Alps en route from Barcelona to Dusseldorf
entry.summary: Mr Winkelmann said the captain on board was experienced and been with the airline and with Germanwings' parent company Lufthansa for more than 10 years and had clocked up 6,000 flying hours on this particular Airbus model.

entry.title: Germanwings crash: Just how safe is the Airbus A320?
entry.summary: Responding to German media speculation that a computer glitch could have forced the plane into a steep dive, Germanwings said they believed that had not caused the crash and that the A320's computer systems were fully updated.

entry.title: Crash is Germanwings' first fatal accident since 2002 start
entry.summary: Lufthansa says Germanwings' lower operating costs helped reduce those losses last year, and that the unit may break even this year.

entry.title: Crash is Germanwings' first fatal accident since 2002 start
entry.summary:
Germanwings, which has a fleet of around 78 aircraft flying to 130 destinations, plays a key role in Lufthansa's effort to compete against low-cost carriers such as Easyjet and Ryanair.

Lufthansa says better results at Germanwings, along with lower fuel costs, should boost earnings for its airlines division - which also includes Swiss, Eurowings, Lufthansa CityLine, Air Dolomiti and Austrian Airlines - this year.

The Germanwings brand will be merged into Eurowings later this year for sales purposes, the airline says, although passengers will still see planes painted with Germanwings markings for the time being and Germanwings flight codes will remain.

entry.title: Crash is Germanwings' first fatal accident since 2002 start
entry.summary: Meanwhile, Germanwings' parent company, Lufthansa, has not recorded a passenger fatality since 1993, when another Airbus A320 overshot a runway in Warsaw, Poland, killing one crew and one of 64 passengers.

entry.title: Why Germanwings flight might have crashed over the Alps
entry.summary: Germanwings Flight 9525 from Barcelona, Spain, to Duesseldorf, Germany, was flown on an Airbus A320, a workhorse of modern aviation, similar to the Boeing 737.

entry.title: Likely reasons why Germanwings Flight 9525 might have crashed over the Alps
entry.summary: This particular jet was delivered to Lufthansa - the parent company of Germanwings - in 1991 and had about 58,300 flight hours over 46,700 flights.

entry.title: Germanwings airliner 4U 9525 crashes in French Alps - 150 reported dead
entry.summary: Germanwings official Oliver Wagner told German television that Germanwings flight 9525 carried 144 passengers and six crew members.

entry.title: Plane carrying 150 went into 8-minute descent before crash in Alps
entry.summary: French emergency services workers, back, and members of the French gendarmerie gather in Seyne in southeastern France on March 24, near the site where a Germanwings Airbus A320 crashed in the French Alps.

entry.title: Jet crashes in Alps with 150 aboard; no survivors expected
entry.summary:
FILE - In this Oct. 16, 2014 an Airbus A 320 of the German airline Germanwings is parked at the airport in Cologne, Germany, as their pilots went on strike.

A Germanwings Airbus plane with at least 142 passengers, two pilots and four flight attendants on board has crashed in the Alps region Tuesday, March 24, 2015.

entry.title: The Latest: witness tells of series of noises before crash
entry.summary:
French Interior Minister Bernard Cazeneuve says 10 helicopters and a military plane have been mobilized to the site in the French Alps where a Germanwings plane crashed en route from Barcelona to Duesseldorf.

A German official says a high school group returning from an exchange in Spain was on board the Germanwings plane that crashed in the French Alps, killing all 150 people onboard.

entry.title: Germanwings Airbus passenger plane crashes in French Alps
entry.summary: This Feb. 24, 2014, file photo shows a Germanwings Airbus A320 in front of the terminal at Koeln-Bonn airport in Cologne, Germany.

entry.title: The Latest: Germanwings still awaiting info on crash
entry.summary: The CEO of Lufthansa, the parent company of Germanwings, says he doesn't yet have any information about what happened to its flight from Barcelona to Duesseldorf that French officials say has crashed in the Alps.

entry.title: The Latest: Germanwings still awaiting info on crash
entry.summary: French President Francois Hollande has spoken briefly with German Chancellor Angela Merkel to express solidarity following the crash of a Germanwings plane in southern France.

entry.title: Germanwings plane crashes in southern France - police
entry.summary:
Two Australians are confirmed as being among 150 people killed when an Airbus operated by Lufthansa's Germanwings budget airline crashed in a remote snowy area of the French Alps on Tuesday.

A rescue helicopter flies over debris of the Germanwings passenger jet, scattered on the mountainside, near Seyne-les-Alpes in the French Alps.

Family members of people involved in the Germanwings plane crash comfort each other as they arrive at Barcelona airport in Spain.

entry.title: Germanwings plane crashes in southern France - police
Black box found at Germanwings plane crash site
entry.summary:
The Airbus A320 operated by Germanwings, a budget subsidiary of Lufthansa, was less than an hour from landing in Duesseldorf on a flight from Barcelona when it unexpectedly went into a rapid descent.

Germanwings said 144 passengers and six crew members were on board.

entry.title: Plane crashes in French Alps with 150 on board
entry.summary:
The Germanwings logo, normally maroon and yellow, was blacked out on its Twitter feed.

The arrivals board shows flight 4U 9525 without a status at the airport in Duesseldorf, Tuesday, March 24, 2015, after the Germanwings passenger jet crashed in the French Alps as it traveled from Barcelona to Duesseldorf.

Germanwings planes at the airport in Cologne, Germany in 2014.

entry.title: No survivors of Germanwings crash in France, police say
entry.summary: Germanwings said the plane started descending one minute after reaching its cruising height and continued losing altitude for eight minutes.

entry.title: The Latest: Germanwings says 150 aboard crash plane
